Remove hacky logic for retrieving the element name from a path

It turns out that our FHIRPathNode object already exposes the element
name from a selected node.
This works for all cases other than inserting an element at position 0
of an empty list, and its not clear from the spec whether that should be
supported or not. Now we throw UnsupportedOperationException in that
case.

I also reduced the visibility of all the patch visitors, added null
checks, and improved documentation of both the visitors and a few select
methods in the FHIRPath model.

issue #679 - fixed major issue caused by use of parent identity

The previous approach failed in certain cases when the Visitable tree
contains the exact same object in multiple different places (e.g. adding
to a name when that same name object is repeated twice in teh same
list).

With this change, the CopyingVisitor now keeps its own pathStack and we
use the normalized path of FHIRPath nodes and/or their parent to ensure
we're only modifying the proper paths in the tree.

timeline.bodyText:
Is the intention of making this an instance method to support inter-mixing other patches with manually added operations like this?
     FHIRPathPatch.builder()
          .add(...)
          .move(...)
          .from(someExistingPatch)
          .from(someOtherPatch)
          .build();
Or were you only thinking of the simple case of just wanting to mutate a single existing immutable FHIRPathPatch?
If you want to allow/support the former, then you should make this method public so anyone can do it. If not, then I'd suggest changing this to an additional private ctor which can only be used by the toBuilder() method of the outer class.
timeline.author: bfelaco

replies.bodyText:
Is the intention of making this an instance method to support inter-mixing other patches with manually added operations like this?

No, although I did consider something like that for supporting combining of disparate patches into a single patch.  I don't think it would be hard to add, but since presently it just naively applies them one-at-a-time, it doesn't make a difference whether you combine them into a single patch or just execute them one-after-another.

Or were you only thinking of the simple case of just wanting to mutate a single existing immutable FHIRPathPatch?

this
I just followed the precedent set in our generated model.  For example, see
https://github.com/IBM/FHIR/blob/master/fhir-model/src/main/java/com/ibm/fhir/model/resource/Account.java#L1381
I think an overloaded [protected] constructor is another option, but I think it just comes down to preference.  @JohnTimm any thoughts on this?
replies.author: lmsurpre

replies.bodyText: Looking at it some more, I guess it wouldn't hurt to just flip this to public...then it could serve both use cases.  I can't think of a downside...
replies.author: lmsurpre

timeline.message:
Convert from to public and add javadoc to FHIRPathPatch builder setters

By converting `FHIRPathPatch.Builder.from(FHIRPathPatch)` to public, its
now possible to combine multiple FHIRPathPatch objects into a single
FHIRPathPatch.

Signed-off-by: Lee Surprenant <lmsurpre@us.ibm.com>
